metadata.title: Synthesis and effect of pegylation on citric acid dendritic nano architectures anchored with cefotaxime sodium

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology

Synthesis and effect of pegylation on citric acid dendritic nano architectures anchored with cefotaxime sodium Viswanath Valikalaa, Induja Santhakumarb, Santhakumar Kannappana,c,⁎
a School of Advanced Sciences, Vellore Institute of Technology, Tamil Nadu, India b Lee Kong Chian School of Medicine, Nanyang Technological University, 59 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 636921, Singapore c Carbon dioxide Research and Green Technology Centre, Vellore Institute of Technology, Tamilnadu, India
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Dendrimers Cephalosporins Cefotaxime sodium Dendritic architecture
A B S T R A C T
In recent years dendrimers have fascinated the investigators towards targeted drug delivery because of their versatile framework and exhibit immense potentiality in entrapping drug moieties through host-guest interactions and serve as a promising vector in biological applications. The current investigation is focused on developing pegylated citric acid cefotaxime dendrimers through the divergent method and its characterization through spectroscopic, microscopic, thermal and microscopic techniques. Among the spectroscopic techniques, 1H NMR and 13C NMR elucidated the key functional groups at various chemical shifts while ESI-MS pointed out the molecular weight of cefotaxime sodium in various generations. Similarly, FTIR, DSC, and AFM investigations detailed that the generations are devoid of incompatibilities, structural deformities and can be opted for targeted drug delivery. The drug entrapment studies and in-vitro drug release studies highlight CFTX G5 containing 92.4% entrapment efficacy and 83.8% drug release in 48 h and specifies a sustain release characteristics. In connection to the above, the in-vivo studies reveal a potent antibacterial activity against various gram-positive and gramnegative microorganisms with a decreased hemolysis and cytotoxicity effects and reflect a high margin of safety regarding pegylated CFTX dendrimers. Further, the antibacterial activities are supported through confocal microscopy that clarified the cellular uptake of dendritic molecules and their internalization.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Dendrimers are hyperbranched macromolecular structures that emanate from core region and can be tailored enough for evincing distinct functionalities such as enhanced molecular size, optimized size distribution and structural characteristics [1]. The hyperbranched architectures were investigated by Vogtle in1978 [2,3], by D. Tomalia in the 1980s [4,5] and independently by Newkome [6]. The hyperbranched structures are also called arborols which means “trees” in Latin and cascade molecules but are not much familiar as dendrimers. Further, the advent of hyperbranched structures explored a massive advancement in synthetic chemistry and amplifies its significance towards inherent biomedical applications such as drug delivery, gene transfection, and imaging [7]. In connection to the dendrimer synthesis, they can be synthesized effectively through conventional methods such as convergent approach [8,9] or divergent approach and furthering through various advanced approaches [10,11]. The dendrimers are considered as the structural motif and exhibit modifications in its size, shape, flexibility, low polydispersity, and low transfection efficacy with
generations. Further, the surface functionalities of hyperbranched structures are amended through its conjugation with diverse bioactive agents that engenders enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR) and enhance drug targeting [12,13], imaging [14,15], diagnostic [16,17], and therapeutic properties [18,19]. This explicit property of dendrimers has fascinated the investigators to study their potentiality in targeted drug delivery systems. In the current investigation, we aimed at developing a dendritic formulation of cefotaxime sodium (CFTX), a semi-synthetic, broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic indicated for the treatment of diverse bacterial infections. The pharmacokinetic parameters specify that intramuscular administration of CFTX exhibits half-life of 1 h, 30% of protein binding, maximum serum concentration of 11.7 μg/ml in 30min which potentially instigated the investigators to develop a suitable formulation that can decrease the cytotoxicity and enhance the pharmacokinetic parameters through effective targeting of bacterial cells alone without targeting the healthier cells. Hence, the demand to develop a novel drug delivery system that meets the biological stipulations and enhance the patient acceptability has potentially motivated us to develop the hyperbranched architectures containing

cefotaxime sodium. Therefore, we aimed to develop dendritic formulations of cefotaxime sodium through the traditional divergent method of synthesis and draw the following conclusions: (1) the hyperbranched structures of higher generation exhibits superior drug encapsulation properties in comparison to the lower ones and generate sustain release characteristics. (2) Predict the drug delivery characteristics through effective host-guest interactions between drug molecules and terminal end surfaces of hyperbranched structures. Apart from the above, it is arduous to predict the allocation of drug molecules in the dendritic cavities and host-guest interactions at the terminal end. Hence, the objective of current exploration relates to overcoming the aforementioned strenuous situations by focusing on effective analytical techniques that manifests an appropriate explanation in generating an optimized formulation.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: All the required solvents were freshly used and procured from chemical suppliers. The synthesis was carried out in normal atmospheric conditions under nitrogen purging and the intermediates and final output were purified using suitable solvents. Citric acid, polyethylene glycol (PEG) 600, sodium carbonate, potassium permanganate, thionyl chloride, dimethyl formamide (DMF), pyridine, N,N-dicyclohexyl carbodiimide, chloroform, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO).

sections.heading: 2.2. Instrumentation and Methods
sections.text: The column chromatography is prepared from silica gel EMD Millipore (40-63 μm) and Davisil® (35-75 μm). Atomic force microscopy studies are performed using Park Systems XE-100 Atomic Force Microscope while Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy is performed using Leica TCS SP2 microscope.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of Specific Compounds
sections.text:
The synthesis of citric acid dendrimers initiates through interaction between 0.175M polyethylene glycol (PEG) 600 and aqueous solution (700ml) containing 4 g of sodium carbonate and 40 g of potassium permanganate under vigorous stirring for 2 h. The mixture thus obtained is cooled to 4 to5°C and at room temperature, it is layered with diethyl ether which results in a biphasic solution containing aqueous and ether phases. The aqueous phase is segregated and subjected to mild heating that results in PEG diacid (Scheme 1) which is considered as the first-generation dendrimer. Further, the resultant was treated with specified quantities of thionyl chloride under magnetic stirring, condensed, incorporated with 20ml of DMF at 70 °C under magnetic stirring and cooled at 10–15 °C for 24 h.While in a separate roundbottomed flask 0.1M of citric acid is dissolved in 10ml of DMF which is in turn incorporated with 3M (125ml) of pyridine and maintained at
10–15 °C for 24 h. Both the reaction mixtures are added one to another and incubated at 60 °C for 6 h for the production of a second-generation dendrimer (Scheme 2). Besides, the obtained product is treated with 5M dimethylformamide and 1MN,N dicyclohexyl carbodiimide, corked well and kept aside for the generation of needle-like crystals. The obtained product is treated with PEG, chloroform and condensed to generate pegylated citric acid plain dendrimer (Scheme 3). Further, 200mg of cefotaxime sodium (CFTX) is dissolved in 2ml of Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and added to 1ml of pegylated citric acid dendrimer under magnetic stirring maintained at 100 rpm for 24 h (Scheme 4).

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy (CLSM)
sections.text: The therapeutic efficacy of dendrimers depends on their effective uptake by the bacterial cells which could be evaluated through CLSM. The human alveolar epithelial cells were cultured in Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS) containing 1% CFTX at 37 °C and 5% CO2. The cellular uptake of dendrimers is investigated through flow cytometry in which each well containing 1.0×105 cultured cells is incubated with pegylated citric acid CFTX dendrimers for 3 to 6 h and analyzed for estimating the intracellular uptake and locations of the hyperbranched structures [20].

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM)
sections.text: The AFM is an exceptional technique for understanding the structural defects of dendrimers in which the hyperbranched structures of various generations are allowed to spray as an ultrathin film on the glass surface through the spin-coating technique. The generated glass substrates are subjected for air drying at room temperature and examined under tapping mode at a frequency of 74 kHz and 87 nm amplitude with the aid of a 7 μm calibrated scanner possessing 5–10 nm radius and 30 N/m spring constant [21,22].

sections.heading: 2.5. In-Vitro Drug Release Studies
sections.text: The in-vitro drug release studies are carried out by placing the predetermined concentrations of dendrimer complex in a dialysis bag whose molecular weight is cutoff between12, 000 to 14,000. The dialysis bag is placed in phosphate buffer saline pH 7.4 and clamped to a tube shaker that rotates 360 degrees. The dialysis bag containing dendrimer conjugate acts as a donor compartment while the beaker containing phosphate buffer pH 7.4 acts as the receptor compartment. Further, at specific time intervals, a known quantity of sample from the receptor compartment is withdrawn and the same is replaced with fresh phosphate buffer solution pH 7.4. The withdrawn samples are adjusted to beer's range using phosphate buffer pH 7.4 and subjected to UV spectroscopy for the estimation of CFTX concentration [23,24].

sections.heading: 2.6. Entrapment Efficacy Studies
sections.text:
The entrapment efficacy investigations help to estimate the

The supernatant liquid was isolated, diluted accordingly with phosphate buffer pH 7.4 and its absorbance was determined at 263 nm [25,26]. The entrapment efficacy is ascertained using the following formula:

sections.heading: 2.7. Hemolytic Toxicity
sections.text:
The fresh blood collected from a healthy donor was centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 10min. to isolate red blood cells (RBC) from plasma. The resultant was washed and suspended in isotonic phosphate buffer solution pH 7.4 to generate suspension containing 2% v/v of hematocrit. The suspension is incubated with various concentrations (0.05–0.5 mg/ ml) of pegylated CFTX dendrimers at 37 °C with 5% CO2 for 24 h under gentle shaking and subjected to UV spectroscopy at 263 nm for estimation of hemoglobin concentration. Simultaneously, the sample suspension is treated with 1% Triton X-100 and the degree of hemolysis is estimated through the following equation:
=%Hemolysis Abs (T. S)–Abs (P. B) Abs (C. H)–Abs (T. S) X 100
where, Abs(T.S) indicates test sample absorbance, Abs(P·S) stands for absorbance of suspension treated with phosphate buffer pH 7.4; Abs (C.H) represents the absorbance of suspension after undergoing complete hemolysis [27,28].

sections.heading: 2.8. Cytotoxicity Studies
sections.text: The cytotoxicity investigations were carried on human alveolar epithelial cells (HAEC), A549 using a standard MTT assay. The cells were suspended in serum-free SHEM-X media containing 10% Bovine serum and incubated at 37 °C for 36 h to confluence the microtiter plates. The media was washed with phosphate buffer saline pH 7.4 and treated with various generations (1–500 μm−1) of plain CFTX dendrimers and pegylated CFTX dendrimers and incubated at 37 °C with 5% CO2 for 24 h. Further, the medium is restored with Alamar blue solution and incubated for 3 h followed by fluorescence determination at 263 nm. The experimental segment refers to SHEM-X media as control, while Triton 0.1% is death control [29,30].

sections.heading: 2.9.1. Preparation of Antibacterial Solution
sections.text: The current exploration recommends S.aureus (ATCC 27853), P. aeruginosa (ATCC 29213), K.Pneumonia (ATCC 10031), H.influenzae (ATCC 9833) as laboratory stains for assessing the antibacterial activity of CFTX dendrimers. The bacterial strains are inoculated with 5ml of Difco's agar media and subjected to overnight incubation at 37 °C and 200 rpm. A prerequisite volume of 400 μl is resuspended with 1ml of nutrient agar media representing 1×109 colony forming units (CFU) per ml. The resultant solution is in turn diluted with nutrient agar media to generate a stock solution of 3.0×105 CFU/ ml [31].

sections.heading: 2.9.2. Antibacterial Assay
sections.text:
The study involves a microdilution technique in which 10 μl of pegylated CFTX dendrimer is incorporated into a 96 well microtiter plate
Scheme 2. a second-generation dendrimer.
Scheme 3. pegylated citric acid plain dendrimer.
containing 100ml of 3.0×105 CFU/ ml bacterial solution. The controlled wells consist of 100 μl of 2.0× 105 CFUml−1 of a bacterial solution without dendrimers and 100 μl of Difco's broth without bacteria. The empty wells are filled with sterile water to enhance the vapor pressure and reduce the rate of evaporation during incubation. The resultant microplates were incubated at 37 °C and 200 rpm for 24 h which resulted in pellets that were resuspended and scanned at 635 nm [32–37]. The dendrimer and CFTX interactions were estimated as fractional inhibitory concentration (FIC) and fractional inhibitory concentration index (FICI) using the equations

sections.heading: 2.10. Pharmacokinetic Investigations
sections.text:
Albino Wistar rats were selected and housed at ambient temperature and humidity conditions and sufficiently fed. The carotenoid artery and
jugular vein of selected rats were cannulated to accelerate intravenous dosing and blood sampling under isoflurane anesthesia. After a full recovery, the rats were injected with 5mg/kg of CFTX dendrimer through the cannulated jugular vein and the urine and fecal samples were collected in regular time intervals and assayed for the estimation of various kinetic parameters. The drug concentration was estimated through the non-compartmental analysis that generated crucial information regarding various pharmacokinetic parameters [33].

sections.heading: 3.1. Synthesis of pegylated citric acid Dendrimers
sections.text: The detailed procedure for pegylated citric acid dendrimers is given in the supplementary file.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Atomic Force Microscopy
sections.text:
The typical images generated by AFM regarding various generations specify a dense molecular pack (Fig. 1a) due to low surface tension and later on emerged as a globular structure (Fig. 1b) due to molecular aggregations at its surface. Practically, it is arduous to generate the
Scheme 4. Pegylated Citric acid CFTX dendrimer.
images of lower generations as they exist as aggregates due to intermolecular attractions and reflects patchy appearance. Further, if each spot is considered as dendrimer molecule, there exist abundant dendrimer clusters that strengthen the above specifications (Fig. 2) and their rigidity enhances proportionately with generations while its adsorption forces decline.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy (CLSM)
sections.text: Further, it can be inferred that the structural deformities might be due to the impact of microscopic tip that plays a key role in imaging and energy deviations between the dendritic molecule and solid surface. Further, the investigations are strengthened through Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy (CLSM) which reveals the internalization of dendrimers in bacterial cells through fluorescence intensity (Figs. 3, 4) that is traced throughout the hyperbranched structure due to the immediate release of dendrimer composition upon interaction with the cellular components.

sections.heading: 3.3. In-Vitro Drug Release and Entrapment Efficacy Studies
sections.text:
The investigative reports highlight CFTX G2 with maximum drug release of 97.4% (Fig. 5) in 48 h with 52.1% entrapment efficacy
(Fig. 6) while CFTX G5 exhibits 83.8% drug release with 92.4% entrapment efficacy. The reason might be due to pegylation that encourages a sustain drug delivery and proliferation of internal cavities concerning size whose complexity enhances with generation and plays a significant role in drug entrapment. Further, the investigations reveal an intense drug release characteristics in the first 2 h due to the drug molecules at the terminal end region. In spite, the release characteristics of CFTX G3 and CFTX G4 are quite satisfactory and still, they don't meet the stipulations because of their deficiencies in the above-mentioned attributes.

sections.heading: 3.4. Hemolytic Toxicity and Cytotoxicity Studies
sections.text:
The cytotoxicity investigations of both CFTX dendrimers and pegylated citric acid CFTX dendrimers are assessed at a series of concentrations (10-500 μm) using the Alamar blue assay method. The investigation refers to SHEM-X media as survival control and triton 0.1% as death control and inferred that the plain dendrimers exhibit 50% cell viability for 50 μm sized dendrimers and 25% cell viability for 500 μm sized dendrimers whereas it is significantly low for pegylated CFTX dendrimers (Fig. 7). Similarly, the hemolytic toxicity because of nonpegylated CFTX dendrimers represents 15.21% to 25.08% (Fig. 8) whereas the same in case of pegylated CFTX dendrimers is confined to 1.6% (Fig. 9). Therefore, the analytical data reveal that the cytotoxicity and hemolytic toxicity are inversely proportional to dendrimers which
are principally due to pegylation that directs the effective interaction of dendrimers with the bacterial cell surface and causes their lysis without targeting the normal cells.

sections.heading: 3.5. Antibacterial Investigations
sections.text: The experimental data reveal S.aureus as the most sensitive organism with MIC of 2.5 μg/ml while H.influenzae exhibits the highest Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) and Minimum Bacterial Concentration (MBC) value of 5000 and 40,000 μg/ml respectively. The MIC data for S.aureus is quite low in CFTX G2 and specifies 1800 μg/ml while the MBC values for the concern are relatively high in other generations (Table 1). Similarly, the pegylated CFTX dendrimers specify the MIC concentrations were reduced effectively in both grampositive and gram-negative bacteria. The MIC values for P. aeruginosa were reduced from 159.8 μg/ml to 79.9 μg/ml, for K.Pneumonia it declined from 634 μg/ml to 317.2 μg/ml, for H.influenzae it deviated from 5000 μg/ml to 86.4 μg/ml (Table 2). On the other hand, the FICI values (Table 3) are significantly low for H.influenzae which details that there exists a potent synergistic effect between CFTX and hyperbranched structures.

sections.heading: 3.6. Pharmacokinetic Investigations
sections.text: The Cmax and Tmax of CFTX pure dendrimers are found to be 9.69 ± 0.7 μg/ml and 0.15 ± 0.015 h while for pegylated CFTX citric acid dendrimers it is pointed out at 13.98 ± 0.031 and 0.39 ± 0.024 because of appreciable drug encapsulation in dendrimer void spaces. The half-life for CFTX pure dendrimers is pointed out at 30min whereas, for pegylated CFTX dendrimers, CFTX G5 discloses the maximum half-life at 51.38min because as the generation proceeds, the dendrimer allocates enough space for drug entrapment and enhances the MRT of the drug molecules. Simultaneously the experimental data related to AUC0→∞ for CFTX pure dendrimers is specified at 23.15 ± 1.2 whereas it specifies elevated values for CFTX G5 dendrimers at 32.64 ± 1.4 which is majorly due to decreased Ke values for the corresponding dendrimers and evinces an inverse proportionality with AUC. Apart from the above, the apparent clearance of the drug for CFTX pure dendrimers is pointed out at 0.125 and decreased for various generations which might be due to protein binding whereas the apparent clearance (Cl /F) reflects a maximum value for CFTX G2 dendrimers as 0.0654 which is principally due to prolonged half-life (t1/2), AUC and decreased elimination rate constant (ke) (Table 4). Concerning Vss/F, it is mainly influenced by tissue penetration of CFTX and does not exhibit a considerable effect on the steady-state volume distribution of drugs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The current investigation reveals the effective synthesis of pegylated citric acid dendrimers using the divergent method. The synthesis highlights the formation of polyethylene glycol diacid, the first generation dendrimer and interacts further in the presence of various activating agents such as dimethylformamide and thionyl chloride for the production of successive generations. The developed strategy can provide adequate quantities of an end product that could be used for investigating the biological activity.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years dendrimers have fascinated the investigators towards targeted drug delivery because of their versatile framework and exhibit immense potentiality in entrapping drug moieties through host-guest interactions and serve as a promising vector in biological applications. The current investigation is focused on developing pegylated citric acid cefotaxime dendrimers through the divergent method and its characterization through spectroscopic, microscopic, thermal and microscopic techniques. Among the spectroscopic techniques, 1H NMR and 13C NMR elucidated the key functional groups at various chemical shifts while ESI-MS pointed out the molecular weight of cefotaxime sodium in various generations. Similarly, FTIR, DSC, and AFM investigations detailed that the generations are devoid of incompatibilities, structural deformities and can be opted for targeted drug delivery. The drug entrapment studies and in-vitro drug release studies highlight CFTX G5 containing 92.4% entrapment efficacy and 83.8% drug release in 48 h and specifies a sustain release characteristics. In connection to the above, the in-vivo studies reveal a potent antibacterial activity against various gram-positive and gramnegative microorganisms with a decreased hemolysis and cytotoxicity effects and reflect a high margin of safety regarding pegylated CFTX dendrimers. Further, the antibacterial activities are supported through confocal microscopy that clarified the cellular uptake of dendritic molecules and their internalization.
